blocks.text: Adult and pediatric regimens, extravasation care, and reaction management.

items: Methylprednisolone 32 mg PO at 12 and 2 hours prior +/- Diphenhydramine 50 mg PO 1 hour prior.
Prednisone 50 mg PO at 13, 7, and 1 hours prior +/- Diphenhydramine 50 mg PO 1 hour prior.
Hydrocortisone 200 mg IV at 5 hours and 1 hour prior + Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV 1 hour prior (urgent settings: NPO/ER/inpatient).
Elevate arm to heart level, apply cool compress, remove rings or tight items.
Observe; consider surgical consult if decreased perfusion, sensation, strength, range of motion, or increasing pain.
Observation: monitor vitals every 15 minutes; preserve IV access.

If associated with hypotension or respiratory distress, treat as anaphylaxis: O2 6-10 L/min by face mask; IV 0.9% NS wide open; elevate legs >60 degrees; epinephrine 0.3 mL of 1 mg/mL IM (or autoinjector) OR 1 mL of 1 mg/10 mL (0.1 mg/mL) IV with flush/IV fluids; call 911/code.
If only skin findings but severe/progressive, consider Diphenhydramine 50 mg PO/IM/IV (may worsen hypotension).
Document reaction and monitor for recurrence post-treatment.
Observe; monitor vitals; preserve IV access.
If progression or hypotension/respiratory distress, treat as anaphylaxis (see below).
Consider Diphenhydramine 50 mg PO/IM/IV for significant skin symptoms (may worsen hypotension).

blocks.text: Hypotension with Tachycardia / Anaphylaxis; Laryngeal Edema (inspiratory stridor); Bronchospasm (expiratory wheeze)

items: O2 6-10 L/min by face mask.
IV 0.9% NS wide open; elevate legs >60 degrees.
Epinephrine 0.3 mL of 1 mg/mL IM (or autoinjector) OR 1 mL of 1 mg/10 mL (0.1 mg/mL) IV with flush/IV fluids.
Activate emergency response / call 911 or Code Blue.
Document reaction and monitor for recurrence post-treatment.
Manage as above (anaphylaxis protocol) and follow institutional code response.
Doses/steps reflect text visible in the provided adult contrast reaction PDF; verify locally for completeness.
Avoid Diphenhydramine if hypotension is present or worsening.
Prednisone 0.5-0.7 mg/kg PO (max 50 mg) + Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg PO (max 50 mg) 1 hour prior.
Hydrocortisone 2 mg/kg IV (max 200 mg) + Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg IV/IM/PO (max 50 mg) 1 hour prior.
Use urgent regimen for NPO/ER/inpatient settings.
Elevate arm to heart level, apply cool compress, remove rings or tight items.
Observe; consider surgical consult if decreased perfusion, sensation, strength, range of motion, or increasing pain.
Observation: monitor vitals every 15 minutes; preserve IV access.

If associated with hypotension or respiratory distress, treat as anaphylaxis: O2 6-10 L/min by face mask; IV 0.9% NS 10-20 mL/kg (max 500-1000 mL); elevate legs >60 degrees; epinephrine IV or IM or autoinjector; call 911/code.
If only skin findings but severe/progressive, consider Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg PO/IM/IV (max 50 mg).
Document reaction and monitor for recurrence post-treatment.
Observe; monitor vitals; preserve IV access.
If progression or hypotension/respiratory distress, treat as anaphylaxis (see below).
Consider Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg PO/IM/IV (max 50 mg) for significant skin symptoms (may worsen hypotension).

items: O2 6-10 L/min by face mask.
IV 0.9% NS 10-20 mL/kg (max 500-1000 mL); elevate legs >60 degrees.
Epinephrine IV or IM or autoinjector (per weight-based dosing/protocol).
Activate emergency response / call 911 or Code Blue.
Document reaction and monitor for recurrence post-treatment.
